text: The number of genes transferred in any one phage capsid is limited, however, to what can fit in the phage head.

Generalized transduction can take any gene from a donor cell and transfer it to a recipient cell, whereas specialized transduction (also known as restricted transduction) can transfer only a few closely linked genes between cells.

The experiments, reported in 1966, showed that a filterable agent, or virus, could carry genetic material between bacterial strains; direct contact between bacteria was a lysogenic cell will prevent the replication of any new phage cell.

Zinder (1928–2012) first suspected that bacteriophages idea, he grew Salmonella in two tubes separated by a fine filter through which viruses could pass, but not bacteria.
There are two basic types of transduction: generalized and specialized.
